Baryali hopes to grow his business and to give his children a good education, so he has requested an individual loan of 30,000 Afghani.

loans.use: To purchase a new part for his taxi

loans.name: Imelda

texts.en: Imelda A., 41 years old, is a single woman who supports her family by operating a general store. She lives in Tabao, Zone 2, Valladolid, Negros Occidental. She work hard to save some money to prepare for when she gets old and still be able to support the needs of her family. Imelda has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2004 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her general store, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of Php 4,500. Imelda is now borrowing Php 19,500 so that she can continue to operate her general store with the new additional working capital. This will be her 10th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of Php 19,500, which she paid off within its term, was just another step in her journey towards economic freedom. Imelda aspires to elevate her family’s living conditions and ensure their future wellbeing by following the “Dungganon” way. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: To use as additional working capital for her general store

loans.name: Julia

texts.en: Julia T. is a 42-year-old married woman who lives in Tabao, Zone 2, Valladolid, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by engaging in a retail store selling dried fish, bananas and other products she she can sell. Julia’s husband works as a driver and also helps her in running the business. They have three children between 3 and 12 years old with two of them currently going to school and also helping out in the business as part of their daily chores. Julia joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 1989 in the hope that she would be able to help her husband improve the quality of life of their family. With the help of her loans from NWTF-PD she has been able to increase their family income by engaging in her business. Now she earns an average monthly income of Php 12,000 from her business activities. Julia is a member of good standing. Her previous loan of Php 25,000 was used to fund operations for her retail business which had a positive impact on both the business and on the family’s living conditions. Now she is borrowing Php 25,000 for her 13th loan, which she intends to use in her retail business. Julia is working hard to achieve her dreams and aspirations for her family, which are to provide them with a brighter future and a more comfortable life. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additonal working capital

loans.name: Milagros

texts.en: Milagros A. is a 51-year-old married woman who supports her family by being a retailer of accessories, by being engaged in catering services, and as a maker of candy and give-away products. She lives in San Gregorio Village, Binalbagan, Negros Occidental with her husband, Alberto, and their 18-year-old child who is currently going to school. Milagros has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2008 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard, her businesses are gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of Php 60,000. Milagros is now borrowing Php 20,000 so that she can continue to purchase additional products for the businesses she has. This will be her 5th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of Php 15,000, which she paid off within its term, was just another step in her journey towards economic freedom. Milagros aspires to elevate her family’s living conditions and ensure their future wellbeing by following the “Dungganon” way. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: To use as additional working capital for her businesses

loans.name: Anita

texts.en:
Anita C. is a 52-year-old woman living in the town of Burgos St., Barangay IV, Hinigaran, Negros Occidental. She is married and has four adult children.

Anita owns and operates a sari sari (general) store, selling a variety of different products in the local community. Anita has been engaged in this business for over fifteen years and earns approximately Php 6,000 a month.

Anita joined NWTF in 2000 to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of Php 19,500 from NWTF.

Anita is now requesting a new loan of Php 19,500 which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. The loan will be her 14th from NWTF. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay her children’s tuition fees.


About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. has answered the calling of not just a few but of thousands of women. Through its alleviation program, these women have progressed from earning less than a measly $1 a day, to surpassing the realities beyond their dreams. They have learned to live a life where they can finally be called honorable. This is Project Dungganon.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Anamae

texts.en:
Anamae R. is a 43-year-old woman living in the town of Sitio San Vicente, Barangay Nanunga, Hinigaran, Negros Occidental. She is a single mother and has one adult child.

Anamae owns and operates a sari sari (general) store, selling a variety of different products in the local community. She has been engaged in this business for over ten years and earns approximately Php 5,000 a month.

In 2001, Anamae joined NWTF to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of Php 29,500 from NWTF.

Anamae is now requesting a new loan of Php 29,000 which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. The loan will be her 15th from NWTF. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay her child’s tuition fees.


About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. has answered the calling of not just a few but of thousands of women. Through its alleviation program, these women have progressed from earning less than a measly $1 a day, to surpassing the realities beyond their dreams. They have learned to live a life where they can finally be called honorable. This is Project Dungganon.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Tung

texts.en:
Mrs. Tung S. is 54 years old, married, and the mother of five children: two are still single and attending school and the others are married. Two of them are employed as grocery sellers.

Tung S. and her husband currently cultivate rice and vegetable crops. In addition, Tung S. is also a local tailor and is hired by her nearby villagers to repair their clothes.

Tun S. is taking out her loan to purchase a motorcycle which she will provide to her employed kids for commuting to their work location.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle for her children to use for commuting

loans.name: Shireen Taj

texts.en:
This is Shireen Taj daughter of A. H.. She lives in the 16th district of Kabul, Afghanistan, and is married with five children. Her youngest son is a college student and the others are in school.

Shireen Taj wants to receive a loan for her husband who has a shop in which he repairs generators. He wants to buy the tools which he needs in his business. Also, he would like to progress his business.

Shireen Taj would like to thank all Kiva lenders a lot.

loans.use: To buy tools for her husband's generator-repair business

loans.name: Chhoeurn

texts.en:
Mrs. Chhoeurn L. is a 31-year-old farmer. She plants rice and some vegetable crops which she will harvest and sell to the buyers when the crops come to maturity. She has a partner in her husband who is a vehicle repairman. He also assists her in farming their crops. This couple has been married for many years and they have a school-aged child who is in the secondary school.

Chhoeurn L. has bought some housing tools in order to build a new house, but the construction has not started due to this process requiring other essential accessories. Chhoeurn L. is asking for a loan to buy extra equipment in order to begin building her new house.

loans.use: To buy extra equipment in order to begin building her new house

loans.name: Kob

texts.en:
Mrs. Kob L. is a villager in Tonle village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns small piece of land on which she cultivates rice to earn a living. Her husband, Mr. Muong Leang, is a village chief who is able to make a small salary to support the family. Her husband is shown on the right in the photo.

Although they try to work hard, they still earn less than needed to support the family. In order to improve their living conditions, Mrs. Kob L. decided to ask for a loan to buy two cows for breeding.

Mrs. Kob L. is the mother of four children, three of whom are employed in a garment factory while the other is attending the local school.

loans.use: To buy two cows for breeding

loans.name: Soem

texts.en:
The person with the smiling face in the photo, Mrs. Soem V., is a 31-year-old woman and a mother. She has given birth to five children: three are married and the others are single. One of her daughters is able to earn money from working in the construction field.

Soem V. has a skill in preparing Khmer tree roots to be effective medicine for administering to patients. Soem V. has a life partner in her husband who is a construction foreman, earning $5 each day.

Soem V. and her family always find it hard traveling to work or anywhere else, because they have no vehicle. Because of the obstacle, Soem V. is therefore applying for a Kiva loan to purchase a used motorcycle in order to supply the family’s needs.

loans.use: To purchase a used motorcycle

loans.name: Khun's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Khun T. is the group leader of five people in Thnuoh village in Takeo province. The members will each use the loan for a different purpose.

Mrs. Khun T. is a farmer who owns a 2-hectare (5-acre) field on which she cultivates rice to earn a living. Her husband, Mr. Seng Suor, is a construction worker.

Although they try to work hard they still earn less income than needed to support the family and they cannot provide better conditions for their family. In order to improve their living conditions, Mrs. Khun T. decided to ask for a loan to add to her savings to build a new house for the family.

Mrs. Khun T. is the mother of four children, one of whom is a garment worker while the others are attending the local school.

loans.use: To add to her saving to build a new house for the family

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en:
Jocelyn E., 46, is making sure that her family has adequate provision for their daily needs. She is married to Noel E., a salesman, and they are blessed with four children. She makes sure that she helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life. She has been selling car batteries for quite some time now.

Jocelyn has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation (CCT) for more than a year now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings* and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow five times from CCT’s cooperative. She is consistent in paying her dues because she used the money she borrowed to expand and improve her business.

Now, with your help, Jocelyn would like to obtain a PHP 12,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital for her expanding business by buying more car batteries of different brands.

Jocelyn dreams that her business will be successful and that she will be able to put up new branches in other locations.


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of fifteen to thirty community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: To buy more car batteries of different brands

loans.name: Shin

texts.en:
Mr. Shin N. is a 37-year-old military policeman. In addition, he also leaves home with his old motorcycle that he uses to deliver fresh fish to sell retail at the client’s house. This operation has the main point of making more income in order to help him be responsible for his family.

Shin N. is a widower and has six school-aged kids who are dependent on his income. Recently Shin N. faced the fact that his existing motorcycle often has broken down during the delivery. Because of this problem happeN., he is looking for a $1,200 loan from Kiva’s partner, HKL. He will use his loan to replace his old motorcycle.

loans.use: To replace his old motorcycle

loans.name: Mrs. Thou Pol Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Thuo P. is 53 years old and she is a village bank president of nineteen people who all live in Kou Doul village in TaK. province. The members of this loan will use the loan to purchase supplies, equipment and other items to support their different businesses.

Mrs. Thuo P. is a farmer who owns 1-hectare (2.5-acre) field on which she cultivates rice. Aside from farming, she is also a pig breeder. Her husband, Mr. Thorn Run, is a motorbike taxi driver from which he is able to earn a small income to support his family.

Since her pig-raising business is going well, Mrs. Thuo P. wants to expand it. Thus, she decided to ask for a loan to buy more piglets and pig feed.

This couple has four children, one of whom is a seamstress in the garment factory, another is a farmer supporting his parents’ business, while the others are students in the local school.

loans.use: To buy more piglets and pig feed

loans.name: Lolita

texts.en: Lolita Q. is a 49-year-old married woman who lives in Martisan, Bacong, Negros Oriental. She earns her living by selling fish. Lolita’s husband, Zamue, sometimes helps his wife in running the business. They have four adult children who are currently employed and help support some of the needs of the family. Lolita joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in March 1999 in the hope that she would be able to help her husband improve the quality of life of their family. With the help of her loans from NWTF-PD she has been able to increase their family income by engaging in fish-vending. Now she earns an average monthly income of Php 20,000. Lolita is a member of good standing. Her previous loan of Php 29,500 was used to fund operations for her fish-vending business which had a positive impact in both the business and the family’s living conditions. Now she is borrowing Php 29,500 for her 16th loan, which she intends to use in her fish-vending business. Lolita is working hard to achieve her dreams and aspirations for her family, which are to provide them with a brighter future and a more comfortable life. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: To use as additional working capital for her fish-vending business

loans.name: Maria

texts.en:
Maria sells iced and dried fish in one of the local markets in Asaba. Dried and iced fish are used in the preparation of mouth watering Nigerian soup. She has been in this business for a long time and uses her experience in business to attract and retain more customers. With this business, she provides the basic family needs.

Maria is a widow with a child and is also a grandmother. She hopes to expand her business but her challenge is funds. She hopes to overcome this challenge. She hopes for a loan of NGN 100,000 to purchase more dried and iced fish to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more iced and dried fish to sell

loans.name: Sinikagni Group

texts.fr:
Les cinq membres du groupe Sinikagni sont  des  femmes mariées ayant une moyenne d’âge de 38 ans et 2 enfants. Elles vivent la plupart dans des familles polygames à Kapaga, Sikasso (3ème région administrative du Mali).
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle et sont à leur troisième  prêt solidaire, après avoir remboursés sans difficulté  les deux prêts précédents. 
Elles font  essentiellement la  transformation des noix de karité en beurre qu’elle vendent au consommateurs et revendeurs.
 Avec leur nouveau prêt, elles comptent acheter chacune, 150kg de noix de karité (pour les transformer en beurre de karité). 
Elles s’approvisionnent dans les villages avoisinants et effectuent leurs ventes, après transformation, à Zéguoa et à Kadiolo ville,  au comptant à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
 Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice mensuel de 15.250FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée pour l’épargne et les besoins de la famille, l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités.
texts.en:
The five members of Sinikagni Group are married women who, on average, are 38 years old and have two children. Most of them live in polygamous families in Kapaga in Sikasso (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They joined the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso in order to meet their customers' needs. This is their third solidarity loan. They repaid their previous two loans without difficulty. Their main activity is producing butter from shea nuts and selling it to consumers and retailers. They will use their new loan to buy each 150 kilograms of shea nuts and transform them into shea butter. They get their supplies in the nearby villages and sell their final product in the cities of Zégoua and Kadiolo for cash to a clientele made up of men and women. They expect to make an average monthly profit of 15,250 CFA francs each, of which part will go into savings and meeting family needs, and the remainder will be reinvested in the business activities.

Translated from French by Robert Mouris, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy shea nuts

loans.name: Mr. Touch Nak Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Mr. Touch N. is the village bank president of a seventeen-member group and all the members live in Chheu Teal Phlouh village in Takeo province. The members of this group will each use the loan to purchase supplies, equipment and other items to support their family’s standard of living, and they hope to increase their income to improve their family’s standard of living, too.

Mr. Touch N. is a farmer who own a 1.5-hectare (3.75-acre) piece of land he uses to cultivate rice. He is also a village chief who earns a small salary to support his family. This couple has five children, one of whom is a bodyguard while the other four are students in the local school.

Mr. Touch N.’s wife, Mrs. Touch Ouk, is a pig breeder. In order to support his wife’s business, Mr. Touch N. decided to ask for 400,000 Riels from AMK to buy pig feed.

loans.use: To buy pig feed for his wife's business

loans.name: Patricia

texts.en:
Patricia is 35 years old; she is a widow with a child. Her child is 15 years old and is in the higher institution in Delta State, Nigeria. Patricia lost her husband five years ago and life has never been the same again.

Patricia is a newspaper vendor and she also sells drinks at retail prices. She has been in these businesses for a long time and uses her experience in business to attract and retain more customers.

Patricia is requesting NGN 100,000 to purchase more newspapers and drinks to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more newspapers and drinks to sell

loans.name: Chea

texts.en:
Mr. Chea B. has been working in the Ministry of the Interior since he was single. Besides this work, he also helps his wife sell a few groceries from home. From this, the family is able to make over $5 per day to solve the family’s financial crisis. This couple was married many years ago, but they don’t have a child.

Chea B. need a loan to repair and decorate his house that frequently has problems.

loans.use: To repair and decorate his house

loans.name: Soutoura Group

texts.fr:
Les cinq membres du groupe Soutoura sont des  femmes mariées ayant une moyenne d’âge de 40 ans et  3 enfants. Elles vivent la plupart dans des familles polygames à Kapaga, Sikasso (3ème région administrative du Mali). 
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle et sont à leur troisième  prêt solidaire, après avoir correctement remboursés les deux prêts précédents. 
Elles font  la transformation des noix de karité en beurre qu’elles vendent.
 Avec leur nouveau prêt, elles comptent acheter chacune 200kg de noix de karité (pour les transformer en beurre de karité). 
Elles s’approvisionnent dans les villages avoisinants et effectuent leurs ventes è Zégoua et à Kadiolo ville, au comptant à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
 Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice mensuel de 17.500FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée pour l’épargne et les besoins de la famille, l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités.
texts.en:
The five members of Soutoura Group are married women who, on average, are 40 years old and have three children. Most of them live in polygamous families in Kapaga in Sikasso (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They joined the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso in order to meet their customers' needs. This is their third solidarity loan. They repaid their previous two loans on schedule. They produce and sell butter from shea nuts. They will use their new loan to buy each 200 kilograms of shea nuts and transform them into shea butter. They get their supplies in the nearby villages and sell their final product in the cities of Zégoua and Kadiolo for cash to a clientele made up of men and women. They expect to make an average monthly profit of 17,500 CFA francs each, of which part will go into savings and meeting family needs, and the remainder will be reinvested in the business activities.

Translated from French by Robert Mouris, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy shea nuts

loans.name: Ngoem

texts.en: Mrs. Ngoem S. is 61 years old and a villager who lives in Angk Prasat village in Takeo province. She and her husband, Mr. Moeun Nao, are farmers who own a 1-hectare field to cultivate rice. Although they try to work hard with their farming, they still earn little income to support their family's living. Thus, Mrs. Ngoem S. decided to ask for a loan to buy a cow for breeding. Mrs. Ngoem S. hopes that this loan will increase her income and improve her family's conditions. This couple has a child who is a painting student. Her husband is on the right in the picture.

loans.use: To buy a cow for breeding

loans.name: Khann

texts.en:
Mrs. Khann N. is 25 years old and lives in Phngeas village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a piece of land to cultivate rice. Her husband, Mr. Chanoeun Khem (pictured left), is a duck breeder who earns a small income to support his family. The couple has two children – the eldest is a student in the local school while the youngest is four years old.
In order to support her husband's business, Mrs. Khann N. is requesting 2,000,000 KHR from Kiva partner, AMK, to buy more ducks for breeding. With this loan, she hopes to increase her family's income and improve their standard of living.

loans.use: To buy more ducks for breeding

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Angela

texts.en:
Angela lives in Asaba, Delta State, Nigeria. She is married to B., a welder, and they are blessed with five children, the eldest of whom is 16 and the youngest of whom is 6. All her children are excelling in their school work.
Angela sells mouthwatering Nigerian cooked foods such as rice, beans, egusi soup (melon soup) and drinks. Her customers love her cooked foods and Angela loves her business because of the one-on-one interaction that she has with her customers.
Angela hopes to expand her business to attract more sales and increase profits. She is requesting a loan of 100,000 NGN to purchase more drinks and foodstuffs to cook and sell. In the future, she hopes to have a classic restaurant. She thanks all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks and foodstuffs

loans.name: Benkadi Group

texts.fr:
Les sept membres du groupe Benkadi sont majoritairement des femmes mariées ayant une moyenne d’âge de 35 ans et 3 enfants. Elles vivent la plupart dans des familles polygames à Noumousso  un des quartiers de la ville de Kadiolo,  Sikasso (3ème région administrative  de la république du Mali). 
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle et sont à leur quatrième  prêt solidaire. Tous les trois  prêts précédents se sont bien dénoués. 
Elles font l’achat et la vente du beurre de karité, des habits  pour enfants, des condiments alimentaires etc.
 Avec leur nouveau prêt, elles comptent acheter,  70 kg de beurre de karité, 3 douzaines d’habits  pour enfants et 5 paquets de condiments alimentaires. 
Elles s’approvisionnent au grand marché de Kadiolo ville et dans les villages avoisinants.  Elles revendent à Kadiolo ville, au marché, de façon fixe les jours de foires et de façon ambulante, au comptant souvent à crédit à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
 Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice mensuel de 17.500 FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée pour l’épargne et les besoins de la famille, l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités.
Elles ambitionnent demander des prêts plus importants pour mieux satisfaire leurs clientèles et  pouvoir devenir grossiste.
texts.en:
The seven members of the Benkadi group are for the most part married, and average 35 years of age with three children. Most live in polygamous families in Noumousso, one of the neighborhoods of Kadiolo, in Sikasso (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They joined the Soro Yiriwaso MFI to satisfy their customers' needs, and are now requesting a fourth group loan. All three preceding loans were well handled. They buy and sell shea butter, children’s clothing, food condiments, etc. With their new loan, they will buy: 70 kilos of shea butter, three dozen sets of children’s clothes and five packages of food condiments. They get their supplies from the main market in Kadiolo and from villages in the surrounding area. They resell in fixed locations on market fair days at the Kadiolo market, and also as itinerant vendors, for cash but often for credit, to a customer base of both men and women. They expect to reach average monthly earnings of 17,500 FCFA each, of which part will go into savings and meeting family needs, and the remainder will be reinvested in the business activities. Their ambition is to request more significant loans to improve customer satisfaction and eventually become wholesalers.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy various items

loans.name: Esther

texts.en:
Esther is 36 years old and married with three children, aged 4, 8 and 15, all of whom attend school. She is a farmer near Kitale, in Kenya's Rift Valley. She has been farming for seven years, cultivating a mixed crop. She sells her milk and eggs through the market and the Kenya Cooperative Creameries, but she also earns income as a maize vendor and by using her posho mill to grind maize for other farmers.
Esther says the main challenges to her business are outbreaks of poultry disease, fluctuations in milk prices, and transportation problems. In the future, she would like to acquire a tractor to till her fields and a vehicle to transport her goods.
She has requested her first loan of 20,000 KES through Kiva partner, Juhudi Kilimo, to expand her poultry business with more chickens. She says the expansion will provide a boost to her family's livelihood.

loans.use: To expand her poultry business

loans.name: Rann

texts.en:
Mrs. Rann S. is 39 years old and a villager from Daom village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a two-hectare field to cultivate rice. Her husband, Mr. Phart Chhoun, is a battery charger who earns a small income to support his family. The couple has four children – one is an electrician, one is a seamstress in a garment factory, while the other two attend a public school.
Although they work hard in their different businesses, they still do not earn sufficient income to support their family. Therefore, Mrs. Rann S. decided to ask for a loan to buy two cows for breeding.

loans.use: To buy two cows for breeding

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Phon

texts.en: Mrs. Phon T. is 67 years old and lives with other family members in Siem Reap province. She is a married housewife who is blessed with four children. All of them are married and live independently. To earn a daily living, Phon T. plants crops as well as raises a few pigs in a pigpen next to her house. She has a life partner in her husband who assists her in this business. In order to earn extra profits, Phon T. has requested a loan to purchase additional pig foods and piglets to breed.

loans.use: To purchase pig food and piglets to breed

loans.name: Zibora

texts.en:
Zibora, a 62-year-old widow with seven children and four grandchildren, is seeking this loan so that she can continue to grow her business enough to provide an education for her grandchildren.  Zibora's farm is near Kitale in Kenya's Rift Valley, where she began mixed farming about ten years ago after many years of just dairy farming. Her main income comes from selling milk to local vendors, and she says that the main challenge to her business is a lack of greater financing.

Zibora has requested this loan through Juhudi Kilimo for Kes. 11,000 to buy more chickens to expand her poultry business.  In the future, she'd like to continue to expand by increasing her maize production and adding fruit crops.

loans.use: To buy more chickens.

loans.name: Siguikadi Group

texts.fr:
Les huit membres du groupe Siguikadi sont majoritairement des  femmes mariées ayant une moyenne d’âge de 38 ans,  2 enfants et vivant la plupart dans des familles polygames à Noumousso  un des quartiers de la ville de Kadiolo,  Sikasso (3ème région administrative de la république du Mali). 
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle et sont à leur quatrième  prêt solidaire. Tous les trois prêts précédents ont été bien remboursés. 
Elles font la vente de beurre de karité et des tasses en plastique.
 Avec leur nouveau prêt, elles comptent acheter chacune, 150kg de beurre de karité, 4 douzaines  de tasses en plastique.  
Elles s’approvisionnent dans les villages avoisinants et au grand marché de la ville de Kadiolo. Elles vendent à Kadiolo ville et au marché les jours de foires, au comptant à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
 Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice mensuel de 35.750 FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée pour l’épargne et les besoins de la famille, l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités.
Elles ambitionnent devenir des grossistes.
texts.en:
The eight members of the Siguikadi group are mainly married women, with in average 38 years of age, two children and most of them live in polygamous families in Noumousso, a neighborhood of the city of Kadiolo, in Sikasso, the third administrative region of the Republic of Mali. They joined the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso in order to meet their customers' needs. This is their fourth solidarity loan and they fully repaid the previous ones. They sell shea butter and plastic bins. With this new loan each of them is planning to buy 150 kg. of shea butter and four dozens of plastic bins. They buy their supplies in the neighbor villages and at the big market in the city of Kadiolo. They sell their products for cash in Kadiolo and at the market on fair days to a customer base of both men and women. They expect to reach average monthly earnings of 35,750 FCFA each, of which part will go into savings and meeting family needs, and the remainder will be reinvested in their business. Their ambition is to become wholesalers.

Translated from French by MONICA URBAN, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of selling items

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace, a 40-year-old married mother of four children ranging in age from 7 to 17, all students, has been farming since she was 18. She has a farm near Kitale, in Kenya's Rift Valley, where she cultivates a mixed crop and runs a dairy and poultry operation, selling her milk and eggs locally.

Grace is requesting this first loan for Kes. 20,000 through Juhudi Kilimo to purchase chickens in order to expand her poultry farming. She says that with the extra income from this business she hopes to help pay for her children's education. In the future, Grace would like to acquire a bigger plot and increase her dairy production.

loans.use: To expand her poultry business.

loans.name: Samuel

texts.en:
Samuel is a 37-year-old married father of three children, ages 11 years, 8 years, and a newborn of just one month. He and his family have a farm near Kitale in Kenya's Rift Valley, where the two older children attend school.

Samuel has been farming his own land for 14 years, having previously worked as a laborer for other farmers. He earns his income as a maize vendor and by selling the eggs from his poultry farming. He says he faced a great challenge this year as severe drought led to low production of maize. He is requesting this loan for Kes. 26,000 through Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow. As his income grows, Samuel hopes to acquire at least two more cows in the future.

loans.use: To buy and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: Jekafo. Group

texts.fr:
Les six membres du groupe Jekafo, 5 femmes mariées  et 1 célibataire ont en moyenne 39 ans, 3 enfants et  vivent la plupart dans des familles monogames à Hamdallaye  un des quartiers de la ville de Sikasso, 3ème région administrative de la république du Mali. 
Elles sont à leur deuxième collaboration avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle. Le prêt précédent  a été bien remboursé. 
Elles font la vente de tissus pour draps de lits, du qoikère, du bois de chauffe,  des parfums, des parures, de la friperie, de la restauration etc.
 Avec leur nouveau prêt, elles comptent acheter, 75kg de tissus pour draps de lits,  2 sacs de 100kg de riz,  6 paquets de condiments alimentaires, 160 sachets de qoikère, 1chargement et demi de camionnette en bois de chauffe,  2  paquets de parfums, 4 paquets de parures et 5 balles de friperie.
Elles s’approvisionnent au grand marché de Sikasso ville et dans les villages environnants.  Elles revendent à Sikasso ville de façon ambulante, à domicile et dans les différents marchés, au comptant souvent à crédit à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
 Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 27.500 FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée pour l’épargne et les besoins de la famille, l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités.
texts.en:
The six members of the Jekafo group – five married women and one who isn't – are on average 39 years old with three children, and live for the most part in monogamous families in Hamdallaye, one of the neighborhoods in Sikasso, in the third administrative region of the Republic of Mali. In response to customer needs they are requesting their second group loan from the Soro Yiriwaso MFI, having fully repaid the first one. They sell fabric to make bed sheets, oatmeal, firewood, perfume, ornaments, second-hand clothing, food preparations, etc. With their new loan they will buy: 75 kilos of fabric for bed sheets, two 100-kilo bags of rice, six packages of food condiments, 160 bags of oatmeal, 1 ½ pickup loads of firewood, two packages of perfume, four packages of ornaments, and five bales of second-hand clothing. They get their supplies from the main market in Sikasso, and from villages in the vicinity. They resell their products inside the town of Sikasso, either as itinerant vendors, from their homes or in the different markets, for cash but often for credit, to a customer base of both men and women. They hope to reach average monthly earnings of 27,500 FCFA each, of which a part will go to savings and taking care of family needs, and the rest will be reinvested in the business activities.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy various items

loans.name: Bina

texts.en:
Bina is 44 years old, married, and has four children. She is a rice farmer who currently owns three-quarters of a hectare of rice field, which she hopes to cultivate. One of her goals in life is to give her children a proper education, and she and her husband work hard to achieve this.
Bina joined Kiva partner, CEVI, a microfinance institution in the Philippines, to gain access to financial services. She says that her previous loans have really helped her a lot, especially because of their low interest rates. Bina is now requesting to borrow 8,000 PHP. She will use this loan to supply her farm with seeds, fertilizers and other inputs.

loans.use: To purchase seeds, fertilizers and other inputs

loans.name: Rita

texts.en: Rita has been selling groceries, drinks and dried fish in Asaba market in Delta State for four years. She is making  progress in her business, and this gives her joy. Rita is requesting a loan of N100,000 to purchase more groceries, drinks and dried fish to sell.  She is married to A., who is a civil servant, and they are blessed with four children, all excelling in their school work. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries, drinks and dried fish to sell

loans.name: Sina

texts.en:
Mrs. Sina N. is 45 years old and lives in Rung village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a 2.5-hectare field to cultivate rice. To support her crop cultivation, she owns a plowing machine. Her husband, Mr. Tha Parnh, owns a rice mill and uses it to earn a small income to support his family. The couple has four children, two of whom are seamstresses in a garment factory, one of whom is a construction worker, while the youngest attends the public school.
In order to increase their income and improve their standard of living, Mrs. Sina N. is requesting a loan of 2,000,000 KHR from Kiva partner, AMK. She will use this loan to buy a cow for breeding and, with the rest of the loan, repair her plowing machine.

loans.use: To buy a cow for breeding

loans.name: Soutoura Group

texts.fr:
Les cinq membres du groupe Soutoura sont des  femmes mariées  ayant une moyenne d’âge de 34 ans et  3 enfants. Elles  vivent la plupart dans des familles monogames à Hamdallaye  un des quartiers de la ville de Sikasso, 3ème région administrative de la république du Mali. 
Elles sont à leur deuxième collaboration avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso  afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle. Le prêt précédent  a été remboursé sans difficulté. 
Elles font la vente d’atiécké, du bois de chauffe et de la restauration.
 Avec leur nouveau prêt, elles comptent acheter, 1sac de 100kg d’atiécké, 1sac de 100kg de riz, 4paquets de condiments alimentaires (pour faire la restauration) et 1 chargement et ½ de camionnette en bois de chauffe. 
Elles s’approvisionnent au grand marché de Sikasso ville et dans les villages environnants. Elles vendent à Sikasso ville et dans les villages environnants  de façon fixe et ambulante, au comptant, souvent à crédit à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
 Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 27.500 FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée pour l’épargne et les besoins de la famille, l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités.
texts.en:
The five members of the Soutoura group are married, and on average are 34 years old with three children. They live for the most part in monogamous families in Hamdallaye, one of the neighborhoods of Sikasso, in the third administrative region of the Republic of Mali. In response to customer needs they are requesting their second group loan from the Soro Yiriwaso MFI, having fully repaid the first one. They sell atiécké (cassava grits), firewood and prepared meals. With their new loan they will buy: one 100-kilo bag of atiecké, one 100-kilo bag of rice, four packages of food condiments (for their catering business), and 1 ½ pickup loads of firewood. They get their supplies from the main market in Sikasso, and from area villages. They resell their products in Sikasso or in the villages, as itinerant vendors or from a fixed location, for cash but often for credit, to a customer base of both men and women. They hope to reach average monthly earnings of 27,500 FCFA each, of which a part will go to savings and taking care of family needs, and the rest reinvested in the business activities.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy various items

loans.name: Dembagnouma Group

texts.fr:
Les quatre membres du groupe Dembagnouma, 3 femmes mariées et 1 veuve, ont en moyenne 38 ans et 4 enfants. Elles vivent majoritairement dans des familles monogames à Médine  un des quartiers de la ville de Sikasso, 3ème région administrative du Mali.
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle et sont à leur troisième prêt solidaire, après avoir correctement remboursés les deux prêts précédents. 
Ce groupe de femmes fait essentiellement  la vente de boissons non alcoolisées, de tissus et  de la restauration. 
Avec leur nouveau prêt, elles comptent acheter, 20 casiers de boissons non alcoolisées, 8 rouleaux de tissus, 1sac de 100kg de riz, 1sac de 150kg de haricot et  5 paquets de condiments alimentaires. 
Elles s’approvisionnent au grand marché de Sikasso ville et dans les villages avoisinants. Elles revendent à Sikasso ville  au comptant,  souvent à crédit à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
 Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 32.250 FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée pour l’épargne et les besoins de la famille, l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités.
texts.en:
The four members of the Dembagnouma group, three married women and one widow, are, on average, 38 years old and have four children. They live mostly in monogamous families in Médine, a district in the city of Sikasso, in the third administrative region of Mali. They collaborate with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso in order to meet the demands of their clients and are on their third joint loan, after having properly repaid the two preceding loans. This group of women mainly sells non-alcoholic beverages, fabric, and prepares and serves food. With their new loan, they plan to buy 20 cases of non-alcoholic beverages, 8 bolts of cloth, a 100 kg sack of rice, a 150 kg sack of beans and 5 packages of condiments. They get their supplies at the main market in Sikasso and in neighboring villages. They sell in Sikasso for cash and often on credit to a clientele of men and women. They each expect to make a monthly profit of 32,250 FCFA, part of which will be put into savings and to meet the needs of their families, and the rest will be invested in their business.

Translated from French by Shannon Arnold, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy various supplies

loans.name: Oeurn

texts.en: Mrs. Oeurn V., a 49-year-old resident of Rung village in Takeo Province, owns a plot of land upon which she cultivates rice. Her husband, Mr. Mao Sem, makes a small income to support his family by renting out wedding decorations and speakers to villagers during wedding ceremonies, parties, etc. To improve sound quality, he wants to buy equalizer for his speakers, and so Mrs. Oeurn V. decided to ask for a loan for this purpose. This couple does not have any children.

loans.use: To buy an equalizer for her husband's business

loans.name: Obiagele

texts.en:
Obiagele is married to a businessman and they are blessed with a two-year-old child. Obiagele sells groceries, drinks and foodstuffs from her store in Delta State. She has been in this business for a long time. She is making positive progress in her business and this gives her joy.
Obiagele is requesting a loan of 50,000 NGN to purchase more groceries, drinks and foodstuffs to sell. She is a good client of Kiva partner, LAPO, and she thanks all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries, drinks and foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Suon

texts.en:
Suon B. is 32 years old. She was married but divorced her husband when her children were very young. Currently, she looks after six children, three of whom are no longer in school and work for a hotel, providing their small incomes to support the family.
Suon B. owns farmland in the village where she farms different types of crops to sell. She lives in a small house which is not able to provide her and her family with a comfortable home. Therefore, she is asking for a loan of $600 USD in order to widen the size of her existing house.

loans.use: To widen the size of her existing house

loans.name: Jekafo Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe Jekafo sont des  femmes mariées  ayant une moyenne d’âge de 40 ans, 4 enfants et vivant dans des familles monogames à Médine  un des quartiers de la ville de Sikasso, 3ème région administrative de la république du Mali. 
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle et sont à leur deuxième  prêt solidaire, après avoir remboursé sans aucune difficulté le premier prêt. 
Ce groupe fait la vente de  savons,  de condiments alimentaires, de médicaments traditionnels et des prestations de services (teinture, tresse etc.)
Avec leur nouveau prêt, elles comptent acheter, 30 cartons de savons, 5 paquets de condiments alimentaires, 1 dizaine de colis de médicaments traditionnels, 5 types de colorants, 50kg de soude caustique et 1 paquet d’ingrédients pour faire la teinture. 
Elles s’approvisionnent au grand marché de Sikasso ville et dans les villages avoisinants. Elles effectuent leurs ventes à Sikasso ville et font leurs  prestations à domicile,  au comptant à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
 Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 32.250 FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée pour l’épargne et les besoins de la famille, l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités.
texts.en:
The member of the group Jekafo are married women averaging 40 years of age and four children each living in monogamous families in Médine, a district in Sikasso City (3rd administrative region of the Republic of Mali). The women are collaborating with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso in order to satisfy the needs of their customers and are now on their second solidarity loan after having repaid the first one without any difficulties at all. This group sells soaps, condiments, and traditional medicines, and it offers a range of services (the dying of cloth, the braiding of hair, etc.) With the new loan, the women of the group intend to buy 30 boxes of soap, 5 packets of condiments, a dozen packages of traditional medicines, 5 types of colorants, 50 kg of caustic soda, and a packet of ingredients for dying cloth. Supplies are gotten from the big market of Sikasso City and from surrounding villages. Sales are made in Sikasso City. The services are offered at home. Cash is accepted from customers composed of men and women. The group members each envision making an average monthly profit of 32,250 francs CFA. A portion of the profits will be put into savings and used for family needs. The other portion will be invested into the businesses.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying various goods

loans.name: Srey

texts.en: Mrs. Srey C. is 38 years old and a mother of four children, all of whom are students in the local school. She is a villager from Roluos village in Takeo province. She and her husband, Mr. Moeun Kean (pictured left), are farmers who own a piece of land to cultivate rice. In addition to farming, Mr. Moeun Kean is a duck seller who earns a small income to support his family. Since Mr. Moeun Kean's business is going so well, Mrs. Srey C. has decided to ask for a loan to buy more ducks to support her husband's business activities.

loans.use: To buy more ducks to support her husband's business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Buy and sell onions and salt

loans.name: Seyi

texts.en:
Seyi is 30 years old and married with two children. She is a Yoruba by tribe, and lives and works in Delta State, Nigeria. Her husband is a carpenter and also supports their home.
Seyi sells groceries and drinks at wholesale and retail prices. She is requesting a loan of 100,000 NGN to purchase more groceries and drinks to sell. She hopes to expand her grocery and drinks business in order to meet the demands of her customers. She says a big thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries and drinks to sell

loans.name: Divina

texts.en: Like other farmers, Divina believes that proper financing is a must in farming. A 47-year-old married woman, she works hard to make her farm productive to be able to cope with the increasing needs of her household. She also joined CEVI last year to have financial support for her farm. She is thankful to have gained access to the microfinance’s program. She is now requesting a loan of 8,000 Philippine pesos. She will use this loan to acquire farm inputs like seeds, fertilizers and others.

loans.use: Seed, fertilizer, etc.

loans.name: Dario

texts.en:
Dario, a 39-year-old farmer, is a father to a one-year-old child. He has been married to his wife Maribel for ten years now. Involved in rice farming, he experienced difficulty especially at times when prices of farm inputs are too high and when the price of rice is too low. But he is determined to work hard despite all these challenges he faces. He also raises pigs to have another source of income.

Dario joined CEVI a year ago and he finds its program very helpful to farmers like him. He is now applying for a loan of 8,000 Philippine pesos. With this amount, Dario would be able to buy seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs he needs.

loans.use: Seed, fertilizer, etc.

loans.name: Nak

texts.en:
Mrs. Nak C. is a 38-year-old married woman who lives in the Prey Ampok village of Takeo province. She and her husband are farmers who own a piece of land to cultivate rice. To increase their income and improve the family's standard of living, Mrs. Nak C. decided to ask for a loan to buy a cow for breeding and to purchase fertilizer, pesticide and gasoline to support her fam crop. 

Aside from farming, her husband is fisherman who earns a small income to support the family. Mrs. Nak C. is a mother of five children, one of whom is farmer, the other three are students in the local school, while the youngest is too young to study or work. Her husband is on the right in the picture.

loans.use: A cow, fertilizer, pesticide, and gasoline

loans.name: Elygito

texts.en: Elygito tills a hectare of rice field. He is 45 years old, married, and has seven children. His oldest child is only 18. He is faced with a challenge of sending all his children to school. Because of the increasing school fees, he works hard to be able to keep up. He grows bananas that he can sell at harvest just to have an extra income. He is also thankful to be introduced to CEVI, an MFI. He thinks its program is exactly what he needs to sustain his farm. He applied for a loan of 6,000 Philippine pesos to supply his farm with seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs it needs.

loans.use: Seed, fertilizer, etc.

loans.name: Jorlyn

texts.en:
Jorlyn is a married woman with three children. She lives in a town in South Cotabato with her family. She is involved in rice farming and currently owns a hectare of rice field. She said that her harvest last time was good and she hopes to double it the next time. She said that all this hard work she does is for her family, especially for her children’s education.

Jorlyn is applying for a loan 6,000 Philippine pesos. She will use it to buy seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs.

loans.use: Seed, fertilizer, etc.

loans.name: Idowu

texts.en: Idowu is 38 years old, married and blessed with two children. Her husband is a lecturer in the higher institution in Asaba, Delta State. Her children are excelling in their school. She sells groceries and foodstuffs at retail prices to her customers. She is doing well in her business but her greatest challenge is funds and she hopes to overcome this challenge. She hopes for a loan amount of 100,000 NIgerian naira to purchase more groceries to sell. She hopes to expand her business in the future. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Grocery store inventory

loans.name: Dy Morng

texts.en:
Mrs. Dy Morng T. is a villager who lives in the village of Chambak Tuem in Takeo province. She is 40 years old, married, and has four children, one of whom has married, while the others are students in the local school. 

Mrs. Dy Morng now is requesting 2,000,000 Riels from AMK to add to her savings to purchase a threshing machine for the business of her married child. Mrs. Dy Morng owns a small store in the local school in which she sells candy, cake, and so on.  Her husband is a teacher and earns a small salary to support the family.

loans.use: To buy a threshing machine

loans.name: Jose

texts.en: Jose is a rice farmer from South Cotabato. He is 32, married and has two children. His oldest child is only seven years old. Aside from farming, he also grows hogs. He hopes to be successful in his ventures. He said that all of this is for his family. He wants his children to have a bright future. He joined CEVI and is now applying for a loan of 8,000 Philippine pesos. He told CEVI that he would use the loan to buy seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs. He would also acquire feed for his hogs.

loans.use: Seed, fertilizer, and pig feed

loans.name: Seng

texts.en:
Seng R., 51, is a resident of Siem Reap, the province of Cambodia, where she has established a small family home and lives with other family members. She is married to Leng Khon, 52, and has five children. Three of her children are married and employed while the remaining two are single and require her financial support. 

Her husband owns a small business fishing fish in and around the river. Seng R. sells fresh fish that she gets from her husband’s fishing and from other fishermen. Recently her husband's catch has frequently suffered from some tools having been ruined. Seng R. would like a loan for her husband to repair his broken tools, as well as to buy new essential accessories for his fishing trade.

loans.use: Repair existing and purchase new fishing equipment

loans.name: Aytmatova Anarhan`s Group

texts.ru:
Айтматова Анархан 57 лет, она замужем и мать 2 сыновей. Оба сыновья находятся в России на заработках. Ее супруг является членом крестьянского хозяйства. Анархан сама работает в сельской школе, учительнецей начальных классов, также в этой же школе работает учительницей  ее единственная невестка. Дома они содержат КРС. В данное время она откармливает корову с теленком. Получаемое молоко она продает в основном соседям. На этот кредит она планирует купить еще одну телку для последующего откорма. В планах на ближайшее время стоит женитьба второго сына и строительства жилья для него. 

Рано, 42 года. Она замужем и воспитывает 3 сыновей. Старшие два сына уже взрослые и работают в России. Ее супруг занимается ремонтом холодильников. у Рано очень интересный и можно сказать красивый бизнес. Она является владельцем собственного свадебного салона. Там она предоставляет услуги по аренде платьев, маникюра и педикюра, а также делает праздничные прически. Этим бизнесом она начала заниматься год назад по совету близкой подружки. Этот кредит будет использован для покупки оборудования, улучшения внутреннего облика салона, а также на покупку новых свадебных платьев. 

Гуллалахон работает парикмахером, кроме этого помогает маме при разведении домашнего скота. Она проживает в своем доме вместе с матерью, 2 братьями. Этот кредит будет использован для закупа 2 голов МРС.   

Кенжахон также занимается животноводством и земледелием. В данное время она откармливает корову с теленком, а также готовится к весеннему посеву. Она замужем и воспитывает 4 детей: по две сына и дочери. Кредит будет использован для закупа 2 МРС для откорма. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan who delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.
texts.en:
Anarhan Aymatova is 57 years old. She is married and is a mother of 2 sons. Both of her sons are working in Russia. Her husband is member of an agricultural collective. Anarhan works as an early-grades teacher at the village school. Her only daughter-in-law also works a teacher at the same school. Anarhan and her family keep cattle at home. Currently, she is raising a cow and a calf. She sells the milk primarily to her neighbors. Anarhan plans to use this loan to buy one more cow for feeding. Her future plans also include a marriage for her second son and building him a home. Rano is 42 years old. She is married and is raising 3 sons. Two older sons are already grown and working in Russia. Her husband is involved in refrigerator repairs. Rano has a very interesting and even beautiful business. She is the owner of a bridal salon. There she offers services such as renting dresses, manicure and pedicure, and also does hair styling. She started this business one year ago on an advice of her close friend. This loan will be used for the purchase of equipment, interior salon improvements and purchase of new wedding dresses. Gullalahon works as a hair stylist and also helps her mother with domestic livestock breeding. She lives in her own house with her mother and 2 brothers. This loan will be used for the purchase of two heads of small livestock. Kenjahon is also involved in animal husbandry and agriculture. Currently, she is raising a cow with a calf and is preparing for the spring planting season. She is married and is raising 4 children: two sons and two daughters. The loan will be used for the purchase of 2 heads of small livestock for feeding.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of one more cow for feeding

loans.name: Sreymom

texts.en:
Mrs. Sreymom T. is 40 years old, married, and lives in the village of Moeang Prachen in Takeo province. Her husband is on the right in the picture. She and her husband are farmers who own a piece of land to cultivate rice. Although they try to work hard with their farming, they still earn too little to support their family adequately. 

Thus, Mrs. Sreymom T. decided to ask for a loan to buy a cow for breeding. With this loan, she hopes to increase her income to improve her family's living conditions. This couple has four children, who all are students, and they also support their parents' business.

loans.use: To buy a cow for breeding

loans.name: Soeurn

texts.en:
Mrs. Soeurn K. is a tailor who owns her own sewing machines. She is fifty-four and a widow with six children. Five of them are students who help with her business when they are not studying, and the other one is married and lives independently. To help with the family's daily expenses, Soeurn's oldest child is employed as a boat driver for tourists.

In order to make her business ever more successful, Soeurn will be using her loan to purchase more sewing supplies. Any remaining money from the loan will be used to decorate her house.

loans.use: To purchase more material for her tailoring business.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is a young hardworking woman. She is 35 years old, married, and has three children. Her husband is a commercial driver in Asaba, Delta State. Her children are excelling in their school.

Mary sells groceries, foodstuffs and drinks at retail prices to her customers. She is doing well in her business but her greatest challenge is funds and she hopes to overcome that challenge. She hopes for a loan of NGN 100,000 to purchase more groceries, foodstuffs and drinks to sell.

Mary hopes to expand her business in the future. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks, foodstuffs and groceries to sell

loans.name: Josefina

texts.en:
Josefina C., 55, is making sure that her family has adequate provision for their daily needs. Widowed and blessed with nine children, she makes sure that she earns well so that their family can have a better life. She has been managing her own variety store for quite some time now.

Josefina has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation (CCT) for more than a year now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings* and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow quite a few times from CCT’s cooperative. She is consistent in paying her dues because she used the money she borrowed to expand and improve her variety store.

Now, with your help, Josefina would like to obtain a PHP 21,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital for her expanding business by buying more quantities of products to be incorporated into her current inventory.

Josefina dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can provide for her children’s education.


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of fifteen to thirty community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: To buy more products for her general store

loans.name: Cherry

texts.en:
Cherry B., 42, is making sure that her family has enough provisions for their daily needs. She has been in the wholesaling and retailing of fabrics for rug-making for eight years now.

Cherry has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow quite a few times in CCT’s Cooperative. She is consistent in paying her dues because she used the money she borrowed to expand and improve her business.     

Now, with your help, she would like to apply for a 34,000 Philippine pesos loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital for her expanding business by buying additional quantities of her products to be incorporated into her current inventory.

She dreams that her business will continue to grow and improve.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: Buying additional fabrics for rug-making business

loans.name: Amangul's Group

texts.ru:
Все члены группы из села Кочкорка. Это село на ходитс я в Кочкорской долине, небольшой высокогорной долине, где зимы порой очень суровые и почти круглый год стоит ветреная погода. Жители этого региона в основном занимаются скотоводством. Амангул Калмамбетова – лидер данной группы. Амангул сорок шесть лет. Её муж – член фермерского хозяйства. Амангул с мужем воспитывают семерых детей: шесть дочерей и одного сына. Старшие две дочери уже замужем. Третья дочь работает официанткой в Бишкеке. Две следующие учатся в соответственно десятом и одиннадцатом классах. Самая младшая дочь также уже ходит в школу. Она учится во втором классе, а сын пока дома. Он ещё не достиг школьного возраста. Содержать такую семью было очень нелегко и муж Амангул все предыдущие годы не жалел собственных сил, чтобы в семье был достаток. Пять лет назад, Амангул решила помочь мужу и учитывая то, положение, в котором она находилась, нашла самое оптимальное решение. Она решила заняться шитьём национальных изделий. Тем более, что дочки к тому времени уже подросли и вполне могли помогать своей матери. Амангул вложила в покупку материалов и принадлежностей три тысячи сомов и начала шить изделия. Её прибыль постепенно росла и теперь, по истечении пяти лет, она составляет шесть тысяч сомов. За это время они выдали дочерей замуж и построили дом. Амангул с большим энтузиазмом смотрит в будущее, так как видит большие перспективы в своём деле. Сейчас она нуждается в кредите, который позволил бы ей купить сырьё для изготовления ватных одеял “жууркан”, а именно двенадцать метров атласа и двенадцать метров сатина. В ближайшем будущем она планирует выдать среднюю дочь заму, приготовить приданое двум другим дочерям и расширять производство посредством вовлечения новых работников.  

У Амангул три партнёра:

Дуйшееву Акылу сорок пять лет. Акыл – отец пятерых детей. Супруга Акыла – домохозяйка, которая активно помогает ему в бизнесе. А сам Акыл изготавливает “ширдаки” – шерстяные паласы. Ему нужен кредит чтобы купить материалы для шитья.

Шарыпжанову Тилекмату пятьдесят один год. Он фермер. У Тилекмата трое сыновей и младший сын помогает ухаживать за скотом. Тилекмату нужен кредит, чтобы купить пять овец. 

Абдыкасымовой Кыял тридцать один год. Муж занимается скотоводством. У Кыял двое детей. Сама изготавливает национальные шерстяные ковры и приданое для девушек. Кыял нужен кредит, чтобы купить материалы.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan who delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.
texts.en:
All of the members of this group are from the Kochkor village. This village is located in the Kochkor valley, which is small valley high up in the mountains, where the winters are at times very severe, and the weather is windy almost all-year-around. The citizens of this region are mainly involved in animal husbandry. Amangul K. is the leader of this group. She is forty-six years old. Her husband is a member of a farm collective. Amangul and her husband are raising seven children: six daughters and one son. Two oldest daughters are already married. Third daughter works as a waitress in Bishkek. Two next ones attend tenth and eleventh grades respectively. The youngest daughter also goes to school. She is in the second grade, and the son is at home for now. He is not of school age yet. It was not easy to support a family like this one, and Amangul’s husband has put all his strengths for years to provide for the family. Amangul decided to help her husband five years ago, and, taking her condition into the consideration, she found the most optimal solution. She decided to start sewing traditional goods. Also, the daughters have grown up by that time and could help their mother. Amangul invested three thousand som into the purchase of fabrics and supplies and began sewing the goods. Her profit gradually rose, and now, after five years, it is now six thousand som. Amangul and her husband married off their daughters and built a house during that time. Amangul looks to the future with much enthusiasm because she sees big opportunities in her business. She now needs a loan in order to purchase materials for making comforters “juurkan.” She needs twelve meters of atlas and twelve meters of satin fabrics. In the near future, Amangul plans to marry off her middle daughter, prepare dowries for two other daughters and expand the business by hiring new workers. Amangul has three partners: Asyl Duysheeva is forty-five years old. She is a mother of five children. Her husband is a member of a farm collective. Asyl makes “shirdaki,” which are wool rugs. She needs a loan in order to purchase materials for sewing. Tilekmat Sharypjanov is fifty-one years old. He is a farmer. He has three sons, and the youngest son helps him take care of livestock. Tilekmat needs a loan to buy five sheep. Kyyal A. is thirty-one years old. Her husband is involved in animal husbandry. Kyyal has two children. She makes traditional wool rugs and dowries for young women. Kyyal needs a loan to purchase materials.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy supplies (12 meters of satin) to make quilts

loans.name: Leonora

texts.en:
Leonora C., 58, is making sure that her family has enough provisions for their daily needs. Widowed and blessed with five children, she is determined to earn a good income so that her family can have a better life.  She is involved in three different types of businesses: her variety store (the main business), her direct selling business, and a buy-and-sell business.

Leonora has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with previous loans, she has been able to borrow seven times from CCT’s Cooperative.  She is consistent in paying her dues because she uses the money she borrows to expand and improve her businesses.     

Now with your help, she would like to apply for a PHP 35,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital by buying more quantities of products for each of her three expanding businesses. She dreams that her businesses will continue to grow so that she can provide for her children’s education.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: buying more quantities of products for each of her businesses

loans.name: Joike

texts.en: Joike is married with 2 children. She is a Yoruba by tribe but she lives and works in Asaba, Delta state. She sells plastics and mouth-watering Nigerian cooked foods such as rice, beans, egusi (melon) soup and drinks. Her customers love her cooked foods. Joike loves this business because of the one-to-one interaction with her customers. She hopes to have a classic restaurant in the future. She hopes for business expansion as this will attract more sales and increase her profit. Joike is requesting a loan in the amount of NGN 120,000 to purchase more plastics, drinks and foodstuffs to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase more plastics, drinks and foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Ifeanyi

texts.en: Ifeanyi owns a pharmacy where he sells medicines at retail prices. His business is very lucrative and he makes a considerable profit from it, which enables him to take good care of his family. He hopes to increase his business in the future but the major challenge is funds, which he hopes to overcome. He is requesting a loan in the amount of NGN 100,000 to purchase more medicines to sell. Ifeanyi is married with six children. He lives with his family in Asaba, Delta state, Nigeria. He says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more medicines to sell

loans.name: Alibekova Sharifahon`s Group

texts.ru:
Село Араван находится в 20 км от южной столицы Кыргызстана - города Ош. Данный район славится своим рисом и развитым животноводством. 

Шарифахон также занимается животноводством. Ей 36 лет, замужем и мать 3 детей. Все они достаточно взрослые и уже помогают родителям в домашнем хозяйстве. Ее супруг работает частным водителем с ежемесячным доходом в около 100 долларов. В данное время они откармливают доенную корову с теленком, также полученное молоко и молочные продукты она реализует в своем селе. Этот кредит запрашивается для закупа еще одного теленка. В будущем семья клиента планирует построить целую конюшню. 

Асияхан, 39 лет, замужем. У нее 5 детей: 3 дочери и 2 сына. Самому старшему 20 лет, а самому младшему всего лишь 3 годика. Ее супруг работает строителем в строительно-монтажном учреждении. Дома они откармливают скот, кредит будет использован для закупа одной телки. скот весной будет отправлен на пастбище. 

Третьим участником этой группы является Январхон, ей 48 лет. Она совместно с супругом занимаются оптовой поставкой продуктов питания местным  школам и детским садам на договорной основе. Этим бизнесом они занимаются 1 год, с тех пор, как супруг уволился с государственной службы. Кредит будет использован для закупа муки, сахара, масло для последующей реализации школам.

ТАйиржан единственный мужчина в группе солидарности. Ему 43 года. Его супруга является членом крестьянского хозяйства. Он занимается животноводством, а также реализацией молока и молочных продуктов. Кредит будет использован для закуп 1 теленка, который потом будет отправлен на горное пастбище. 

Садатхан замужем и воспитывает 2 детей. Старшему сыну 28 лет, он строитель, а дочери 22 года, она домохозяйка. У них семейный бизнес по выращиванию сельхоз культур и откорму скота. В данное вреия они содержат 4 овца, также готовять к посеву картофеля. Кредит будет использован для закупа 5 овец.  
  

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan who delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.
texts.en:
The Aravan village is located 20 km from the southern capital of Kyrgyzstan, the city of Osh. This region is famous for its rice and a well-developed animal husbandry. Sharifahon is also involved in animal husbandry. She is 36 years old, married and is a mother of 3 children. All of them are fairly grown and already help their parents with the household. Her husband works as a private driver and has a monthly income of about 100 dollars. Currently, they are raising a dairy cow and a calf. Sharifahon also sells milk and dairy products in their village. She is requesting this loan for the purchase of one more calf. In the future, the client’s family plans to build a horse stable. Asiyahan is 39 years and married. She has 5 children: 3 daughters and 2 sons. The oldest is 20 years old, and the youngest is only three. Her husband is a construction worker at a construction company. Asiyahan and her husband raise livestock at home. The loan will be used for the purchase of one cow. The livestock will be sent to pasture in the spring. The third participant of this group is Yanvarhon, who is 48 years old. Together with her husband, she is involved in wholesale delivery of food products to local schools and kindergartens on a contract basis.
